overview: The purpose of this Act is to permanently establish the women's court program in the first circuit and establish a two-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit. [13] The measure requires the judiciary to submit reports to the legislature regarding the pilot program for women's court. [13] This Act shall take effect on July 1, 2025; provided that part III shall be repealed on June 30, 2027. [13]
appropriations: There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $514,900 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027. [13] The funds are for mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services and equipment. [13] The appropriation also funds the establishment of one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position for the women's court pilot program. [13]
agency_impact: There shall be established within the third circuit Kona division of the judiciary the women's court pilot program. [13] The women's court pilot program shall be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [13] The judiciary shall be responsible for providing mental health services under this pilot program. [13]
policy_impact: The measure codifies the Women's Court Program in the First Circuit within the Hawaii Revised Statutes, rather than the Session Laws of Hawaii. [14] The duration of the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit has been changed from three years to two years. [14] The bill deletes language that would have required the Judiciary to submit a report to the Legislature regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for Women's Court in the Second and Fifth Circuits and Hilo division of the Third Circuit. [14]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The measure appropriates $514,900 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027 for the two-year Women's Court Pilot Program. [14] The funds are for mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services and equipment, and the establishment of one full-time equivalent temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position. [14] The Women's Court Program in the First Circuit is permanently established. [14] The pilot program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit has a sunset date of June 30, 2027. [14]
capital_expenditure_impact: Appropriated funds are designated for mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services and equipment. [13] The specific cost allocation for equipment is not detailed in the measure. [13]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The women's court program in the first circuit is permanently established, which will have ongoing fiscal implications beyond the six-year period. [13] The women's court pilot program in the Kona division of the third circuit is repealed on June 30, 2027. [13]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The duration of the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit was changed from three years to two years. [14] The measure now includes specific appropriations of $514,900 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027, replacing previously unspecified amounts. [14] The Judiciary is now responsible for providing mental health services under the pilot program. [14] The bill now establishes one temporary full-time equivalent Kona drug court probation supervisor position. [14] Language requiring the Judiciary to report on the need for similar pilot programs in other circuits has been deleted. [14] The sunset date for the Kona pilot program has been changed to June 30, 2027. [14]
